Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \\), where \\( u(t) \\) and \\( v(t) \\) are real functions of time, evolved under the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Pz \\) with \\( P \\) being a constant matrix. We also incorporate the transformation \\( h(z) = e^{Qt}z \\), where \\( Q \\) is another constant matrix, to observe changes over time t.

Can the original complex number \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 be exactly deduced after observing \\( z(t) \\) at t = T without knowing whether \\( h(z) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowledge of the application of \\( h(z) \\), it is impossible to determine whether the observed \\( z(t) \\) at T was directly evolved from \\( z_0 \\) or transformed by \\( e^{Qt} \\). The initial condition's modification by \\( e^{Qt} \\) may be non-reversible, especially if Q does not commute with P, thus leaving ambiguity.
